elements.title: 280 Broadway (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that 280 Broadway (pictured), once called the "cradle of the department store", later hosted The Sun newspaper and then the New York City Department of Buildings?

elements.title: Rafael Quispe (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Aymara legislator Rafael Quispe's humorous style of political activism led one Bolivian parliamentarian to describe him as the "Chapulín Colorado" of the Legislative Assembly?

elements.title: Iranian satellite (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Russia launched an Iranian satellite into orbit just three weeks after Putin and Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Khamenei vowed to cooperate against the West?

elements.title: Theodore Silverstein (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that medieval literature scholar Theodore Silverstein's unit in World War II took over the Eiffel Tower to intercept communications of German aircraft?

elements.title: golden logistics triangle (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Office for National Statistics defines a golden logistics triangle in the English Midlands that lies within four hours driving distance of 90% of the British population?

elements.title: Harry Lipsig (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that "King of Torts" Harry Lipsig persuaded a jury that a man had been scared to death by a car?

elements.title: tallest captive elephant in Asia (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the tallest captive elephant in Asia has been commemorated in verse, sculpture and film?

elements.title: Daniel C. Darrow (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the pediatrician Daniel C. Darrow "was tolerant of students, but they were rather terrified of him"?
